description: Number of near-repunit primes can be formed from (10^k-1)/9 by changing just one digit from 1 to 0.
references: C. K. Caldwell and H. Dubner, The near repunits primes, J. Rec. Math., Vol. 27(1), 35-41. 1995.
links: Charles R Greathouse IV, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..2000
Chris Caldwell, Below are all of the 12-digit Near-Repunit primes:
example: a(12) = 5 because from (10^12 -1)/9 = 111111111111, by changing just one digit from 1 to 0, out of the eleven candidates, 111111111101, 111111110111, 111111011111, 111011111111 and 101111111111 are primes.
mathematica: a = {}; Do[ p = IntegerDigits[ (10^n - 1)/9 ]; c = 0; Do[ If[ q = FromDigits[ ReplacePart[p, 0, i]]; PrimeQ[q], c++ ], {i, 2, n} ]; a = Append[a, c], {n, 1, 100} ]; a - _Robert G. Wilson v_, Nov 19 2001
author: _Felice Russo_
extensions: More terms from _Robert G. Wilson v_, Nov 19 2001
Edited by _N. J. A. Sloane_, Oct 02 2008 at the suggestion of R. J. Mathar
